dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, B, there's been a lot of talk, um, still, about the AstraZeneca vaccine and these blood clot concerns.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, B, there's been a lot of talk, um, still, about the AstraZeneca vaccine and these blood clot concerns.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: AstraZeneca on Sunday insisted that is Covid-19 vaccine was safe citing a review of safety data from inoculated people which found no evidence of increased risk of blood clots, as the Netherlands, Ireland and now Germany became the latest countries to suspend the use of the vaccine following reports of possible side effects including blood clots.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Insisting its vaccine is safe, AstraZeneca said it had reviewed safety data of more than 17 million people vaccinated in the European Union and the U.K. and found no evidence of an increased risk of pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis or thrombocytopenia...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which, you know, is what you'd expect. But then, almost immediately, we saw countries like, um, the Netherlands, Ireland, and Germany, like, pausing or at least looking really closely at its use.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. Germany, especially, had a bit of a back-and-forth. They actually initially called it "highly ineffective," but then decided to continue using it, even after serious thrombotic events were being investigated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. Germany, especially, had a bit of a back and forth. They actually initially called it highly ineffective, but then decided to continue using it, even after serious thrombotic events were being investigated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Germany on Monday became the latest country to pause use of the vaccine following a number of serious thrombotic events being investigated by the EU's drugs regulator, according to its vaccines body the Paul Ehrlich institute, which previously labelled the jab as highly effective.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's wild. So, on one hand, they're saying it's ineffective, then they're like, "Okay, let's keep going." And the Netherlands even, uh, announced they'd *increase* its use, citing "beneficial side effects" reports from Denmark and Norway. I mean, what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's wild. So, on one hand, they're saying it's ineffective, then they're like, Okay, let's keep going. And the Netherlands even, uh, announced they'd increase its use, citing beneficial side effects reports from Denmark and Norway. I mean, what?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Netherlands announced on Sunday that the use of the AstraZeneca jab will be suspended at least until March 29 as a precaution after reports of unexpected possible side effects in Denmark and Norway.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Insisting its vaccine is safe, AstraZeneca said it had reviewed safety data of more than 17 million people vaccinated in the European Union and the U.K. and found no evidence of an increased risk of pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis or thrombocytopenia, in any defined age group, gender, batch or in any particular country, Reuters reported.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so they're really sticking to their guns. But then you have, um, the World Health Organization, or at least their Chief Scientist, Dr. Soumya Swaminathan, saying, "It is clear that the vaccine is causing the blood clots."

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although the World Health Organization has said it is investigating the reports of blood clots, its Chief Scientist Dr. Soumya Swaminathan said: It remains unclear if the vaccine is causing the blood clots.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: She then added: The adverse events which are reported after vaccination have to be seen in the context of events which occur naturally in the population.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Last week, Austria stopped using a batch of AstraZeneca shots while investigating the death of a 49-year-old woman who died from blood clots 10 days after being administered the vaccine.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the European Medicines Agency, the EMA, actually chimed in on *that specific case*, saying their preliminary probe found the vaccine *definitely* caused the clotting and the death.
